Fields.DialogueText: The Kapitan was lucky to have survived the blast, considering how close the bomb was when it exploded. The medical officer said the Kapitan is still unconscious, but all the vital signs look okay.
Things could have been a lot worse, so let's count our blessings. I can't believe Yuri tried to blow up the whole ship! Thankfully, now that the fire's out, it looks like there's no major damage.
Da, I can sense the ship will be fine - but I will never forgive Yuri for this!

Fields.MenuText: I think the Captain will be okay, so don't worry.
Yuri is still locked in the brig. What should we do with him?
That's right - a Belle can sense everything going on with their ship, right?

Fields.DialogueText: The Kapitan is strong and a fighter. Yuri will pay dearly for his actions!
If it were up to me, the only question would be which direction to throw Yuri overboard - starboard or port. However, the Kapitan is the only one who can decide what to do with that rat.
In a general sense, yes - but somehow Yuri was able to plant his bombs without me noticing. I have been getting headaches lately, so it has been difficult to concentrate...
I'm sure the Captain will come to soon enough. We can figure out what to do with Yuri after that.
Da, although by imprisoning a Party representative, I am sure Moskva will label all of us as traitors.
Yuri does have the full backing of the Party, or at least that's what he's always told us. The Captain's going to wake up to a hell of a predicament...
Da, but we need to continue fighting the Rusalki on our own until the Kapitan awakens!
Aye, Lady Voroshilov! It looks like we've got a few Morganas ahead of us already!
@BATTLE
Voroshilov...
Kapitan!
What... what happened? Where am I?
We were looking for Yuri's last bomb - do you remember? You were right next to it when it exploded. You are lucky to be alive!
Oh... right... yes, I remember the first part - but an explosion?! Were any other crew members hurt?
A few with minor injuries, but you were the only one caught directly in the blast.
Thank goodness - and the ship? Any damage?
The bomb blew a hole in the deck, and there was a fire, but the crew put it out. The hull is still intact, and there was no structural damage.
I suppose things could be a lot worse. That Yuri - he's a real piece of... work!
Da, Kapitan - I could not agree more! Once you are feeling better, we need to decide what to do with him. We are likely already traitors in the eyes of Moskva for locking Yuri up.

Fields.MenuText: Locking up Yuri was absolutely necessary for the safety of the crew and ship.
It won't be easy, but we can figure out how to handle things with Moscow.
Moscow won't know anything if we get rid of their little spy...

Fields.DialogueText: Are you suggesting what I think you are? I do not approve of such things, Kapitan! In any case, Yuri has countless spies on our crew. It would be another great purge to silence all the witnesses...
My apologies - that was a horrible thing to suggest! The man did almost kill me, though...
Da, Kapitan, but we still need to figure out what to do once Moskva gets word of our actions.
Da, Kapitan. Yuri is a very high-ranking Party member, though. Convincing them that he is a criminal will be difficult.
Even after everything he did, Yuri still has leverage over us when it comes to the Red Fleet and the Party. It's ridiculous, but we need to talk to Yuri to work something out.
Da, Kapitan. It seems there is no other choice.
*GUNFIRE*
Please rest, Kapitan! I will take care of the Rusalki!
Thanks - I can always count on you, Voroshilov!
@BATTLE
Ah, Kapitan! I heard you had the opportunity to inspect one of my bombs up close and in person!
You are a digusting rat, Yuri...
I am more like a zoo animal locked up in this cage, Comrade Voroshilov. Surely I must be more interesting than a common rat!

Fields.MenuText: Why did you decide to blow up the ship?
How did the bomb go off when you were already in the brig?
How were you planning to escape a sinking ship?

Fields.DialogueText: It became obvious that regardless of the outcome of our experiments, Comrade Voroshilov will always be a greater risk than an asset. I just wish everyone in the Party saw things the same way...
Ha! I have more allies on the crew than you realize, Kapitan!
Ha! You expect me to tell you everything just because you have me locked up? We both know I still have the upper hand.
Well, I hate to break it to you, but you failed, Yuri. We took care of your bombs, and the ship is still afloat. Voroshilov isn't going anywhere.
I will always support the Party and the Soviet Union, but I can only hope for the worst fate for you, Yuri.
Well, it is true that not everyone in the Party agreed with my methods, but I still have their trust, Comrade Voroshilov.
Trust? You are making life-and-death judgments based on ridiculous accusations and a complete lack of evidence!
My little Voroshilova! Do you really think the Party cares what happens to one little ship floating in circles in the Black Sea? The Party has hundreds of higher priorities!
But what if I really can read the mind of Marshal Voroshilov? That sounds like a high priority to me, Yuri Ivanovich!
You have been spending all this time denying such a thing! In any case, the truth is no longer so important, Comrade Voroshilov.
The only thing that matters is what I tell the Party! You can sail for days - weeks even, but you will never escape the reach of Moskva!
@BATTLE
Well, if you ask me, I think we should just throw Yuri overboard in the middle of the night and be done with it...
You know we can't do that, Petty Officer Jones.
Just offering my personal opinion on the matter, Captain. It's your decision, of course.
We need to threaten Yuri somehow, Kapitan. He knows we will have to answer to the Party when we return to port. Is there any way we can get Yuri on our side?

Fields.MenuText: It'll be tough to get Yuri on our side after everything that's happened between us...
Hmm... interesting idea, but how can we convince Yuri to support us?
Maybe we should just never return...

Fields.DialogueText: Nyet, Kapitan. As much as I hate Yuri, he is right - we cannot run forever. At some point, we have to explain what happened to Moskva - and Yuri's word will always carry more weight than ours.
Da, Kapitan - but I do not see any other option. Yuri is a high-ranking Party member, and it will be nearly impossible to convince the leadership that he is a criminal.
Asking Yuri nicely does not seem like a realistic option, Kapitan. That is why I feel some kind of threat or bargain is more likely to work...
We'll need some kind of huge threat or an even bigger bribe to convince Yuri to be on our side once we finally get back.
Can't think of anything good off the top of my head, Captain. Maybe we should talk to Yuri a little more to figure out what kinds of things could motivate him.
I am afraid I am also lacking in ideas, Kapitan.
Well, we don't have forever, but we do have some time to think of a plan. Our orders from the Red Fleet have us patrolling the Black Sea for a few more weeks before returning to a Soviet port.
We can continue to fight the Rusalki while thinking about a solution for our Yuri problem, Kapitan!
@BATTLE
I had another dream last night, Kapitan.
From the look on your face, I'm guessing it wasn't a good dream?
Nyet, Kapitan. Does anyone have good dreams these days?
I still do - once in a while. Waking up to reality is always the disappointing part.
It was another dream about... him.
Marshal Voroshilov?
Da, Kapitan.

Fields.MenuText: So you really can read his mind?
Hopefully it wasn't as terrible as your dream about Marshal Voroshilov in Finland...
I suppose we can talk about this openly. Even if Yuri's spies are listening, we've still got Yuri locked up.

Fields.DialogueText: I really do not know, Kapitan. These dreams feel so real...
In some ways yes, and in other ways no, Kapitan...
Figuring out the truth is not important to Yuri anymore - he told us himself.
So what did you see in the dream?
It was a list of thirteen names, Kapitan. Marshal Voroshilov held the list in his hands, and was ready to sign his approval at the bottom.
Approval? Approval for what?
It was an execution order, Kapitan. His approval was... to execute the men on the list.
@BATTLE
We're going to have to turn you in, Yuri. I don't care how high up in the Party you are - you attempted to blow up a Red Fleet ship, nearly killing hundreds of Soviet and Neutrality Fleet sailors!
I have already told you, Kapitan - your accusations and hypothetical statistics are meaningless to the Party! Holding me in this prison will not change that!
The only thing that matters to the Party is what I tell them. Unfortunately for you, what I will tell them is that you are a counterrevolutionary who locked up a Party representative!

Fields.MenuText: What do you want from us, Yuri?

Fields.DialogueText: What do I want from you? Ha! You really think I need anything from you, Kapitan?

Fields.MenuText: What'll it take to convince you to change your mind?

Fields.DialogueText: You speak as if you have something to offer, Kapitan - but unfortunately I have no need for anything you could provide.

Fields.MenuText: If you want to see the outside of this cage, you'll have to cooperate with us.

Fields.DialogueText: Kapitan, I assure you I will see the outside of this cage shortly after we return to a Soviet harbor. The tables will turn rather quickly, so be prepared...
We have done nothing wrong, Yuri. What would you expect a kapitan to do with someone trying to sink their ship? Let them do as they please?
I do not blame you or the Kapitan for your response. In fact, your  treatment of me has been rather... civilized. I do wish the bed was a little more comfortable in this cell, though...
So what will happen when we return to land?
I will have the Kapitan arrested, and this ship will be dry-docked until the end of the war - if not longer. That sounds like a sensible course of action to me.
I will not allow any of this to happen, Yuri!
You are a security threat as long as you exist, Comrade Voroshilov. The sooner you accept this, the easier it will be to deal with your fate.
It is just unfortunate that you dragged the good Kapitan into your troubles as well.
@BATTLE
Nothing we say ever seems to threaten him...
Yuri is confident that his place in the Party will keep him safe no matter what.
There's got to be something we can do... maybe threaten Yuri's family? Reveal some dark secrets about his past? Bribe him?

Fields.MenuText: It doesn't help that we hardly know anything about the man.
Yuri doesn't seem to want to bargain with us at all.
We could try using force, but that goes against my personal code of ethics.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh believe me, Kaptain - if force was on the table, I'd be more than happy to help out at this point - but we all know we couldn't do something like that.
My country's dossier on Mr. Yuri has more questions than answers, Captain. Sorry I can't help much either.
That's why we've got to find something that threatens him, Captain! We need to force Yuri to want to negotiate with us.
We need to find a solution quickly, Kapitan. Yuri is right - at some point we will have to return to the Soviet Union.
... and whenever that happens, you'll have to explain why you've kept their Party representative locked up for weeks in the brig.
We should have gone with your original idea of throwing Yuri overboard, Petty Officer Jones...
No one ever listens to my great ideas, Captain - but I'm sure the Party would arrest you for that too.
I just don't like the fact that doing the responsible thing by protecting my ship and crew is going to get me arrested...
Yuri is right - I am horrible for dragging you into my troubles, Kapitan!
Don't blame yourself for this, Voroshilov! We'll figure things out...
@BATTLE
I had the same dream again last night, Kapitan.
The one where Marshal Voroshilov is signing off on execution orders?
Da, Kapitan - and I have had a headache all day after waking.

Fields.MenuText: If it was the same list as the last dream, it's more likely a memory than mind reading.
Headaches? Have you had those after bad dreams before?
Anything different about the dream this time?

Fields.DialogueText: Da, Kapitan - I agree with you. It felt more like watching a movie than being inside someone's mind...
Nyet, Kapitan - this is an entirely new phenomenon.
Nyet, Kapitan - it was the exact same dream as last time.
It seems like you have some access to Marshal Voroshilov's memories, but nothing so far seems to indicate you can read his mind in the present day.
Da, Kapitan... that reminds me of a small detail I remember from the dream! The list of 13 names for execution - the date at the bottom of the page read "1937."
Hmm... so this memory is already from a few years ago.
Da, from the Yezhovshchina - the great purges that took place in 1937.
Such a tragedy... but I wonder why you keep having this dream now?
I... I'm not sure, Kapitan. I just wish this headache would go away...
*GUNFIRE*
Life is full of headaches, Voroshilov! Speaking of which, let's take care of these Morganas!
Da, Kapitan!
@BATTLE
What is wrong with you, my little Voroshilova?
Nothing, Yuri! The only one wrong here is you - and that is why you are locked in the brig!
These retorts of yours are beginning to sound more childish than clever, Comrade Voroshilov. It is obvious that something is bothering you.
Headaches again, Voroshilov?
Da, Kapitan...
If I may continue, Kapitan - my allies on your crew have already sent word to Moskva about what has transpired on board.
I determined that Voroshilov is a security threat that needs to be eliminated, and the Kapitan disagreed and threw the Party representative in the brig.
So, you should receive orders shortly to return to a Soviet port. At that point, I will be freed and you will be arrested. Voroshilov will be placed in dry dock, and we can all get on with our lives.

Fields.MenuText: That's not how things are going to go, Yuri.
So the Party isn't concerned that you were about to destroy a ship and murder hundreds of innocent Soviet sailors?
This ship will never return to the Soviet Union.

Fields.DialogueText: Ha! How will you fuel your ship? Feed and pay your crew? Unless you are ready to embrace life as a pirate vessel, you will return to Rossiya, Kapitan.
You speak as if the Party has never made such calculations before for the benefit of the Soviet Union, Kapitan. Marshal Voroshilov himself has executed far greater numbers in the name of progress.
That is exactly how things will go, Kapitan - because those are the instructions I have sent to the Party. I just hope they have some caviar waiting when they welcome me back...
How can the Party tolerate such rotten members as you in their ranks?
Rotten? I suppose I would be a little more fresh if your guards would allow me to shower more often.
You are not making decisions to support the revolution, Yuri - you are making decisions out of fear! Is this how the Party conducts itself?
This is how the Party has always conducted itself, my little Voroshilova!
*BOOM*
Sounds like another visit from our Morgana friends...
I have nothing more to say to this rat anyway, Kapitan. Let us go and sink these Rusalki!
@BATTLE
Where are we, Kapitan?
I made a slight change in course last night. We're in Turkey, Voroshilov.
Turtsiya? Ah - I see, Kapitan! Turtsiya is still neutral, so we can dock without the threat of Party interference.
Exactly. It's not a permanent solution, but at least it'll buy us a little more time.
We won't be back at sea until tomorrow, so you can relax for the rest of the day, Voroshilov.
Relax? I am not sure I know what that feels like, Kapitan. I have been watched and studied since the moment I came into this world. What do people normally do to relax?
Well... a lot of people have hobbies - you know, activities they do for fun that aren't considered work.
I am having trouble understanding what you mean, Kapitan.

Fields.MenuText: Hmm... well, what kinds of activities do you enjoy doing in your normal routine?

Fields.DialogueText: I hate dealing with Yuri, Kapitan. However, I always feel a sense of accomplishment whenever we win over the Rusalki.
I guess sinking Morganas counts as a hobby when you're talking about Belles...
*GUNFIRE*
Morganas in the harbor, Captain!
Let us do some relaxing with the Rusalki, Kapitan!
I suppose it's as good a hobby as any, Voroshilov!
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: Yeah, I don't have any either, anymore. Must be nice, though.

Fields.DialogueText: If you say so.
Anyway, I guess sinking Morganas counts as a hobby when you're talking about Belles.

Fields.MenuText: I refuse to believe you don't understand what I'm talking about. You know what the crew does in their off-hours, if nothing else.

Fields.DialogueText: *shudder*
Kapitan! I had the dream again!
The same dream about Marshal Voroshilov signing the execution orders? You seem awfully excited about it this time.
Da, Kapitan! I realized something about the dream this time...

Fields.MenuText: It's strange to see you this excited. You're usually complaining about headaches lately.
I'm glad that dream is making you excited about something - the subject matter is grim no matter what.
I suppose the third time's a charm?

Fields.DialogueText: Well, I am still getting the headaches, Kapitan - but this latest realization makes everything worthwhile!
Da, Kapitan - my realization is the only positive thing to come out of such a horrible memory.
It seems so, Kapitan - but maybe there was a reason why the dream kept recurring.
Okay, so what was it that you realized this time?
The execution list was dated "1937" and had 13 names, Kapitan. Marshal Voroshilov signed his name on the bottom to approve of the killings.
Right. You mentioned all of this before...
Da, Kapitan, but when I had the dream again last night, I noticed the last name on the execution list was--
Yuri Ivanovich Volkov!
@BATTLE
So what is this that you've made again, Petty Officer Jones?
Jellied eels, Captain! I thought I'd make a dish from back home to celebrate the breakthrough in our Yuri problem.
To be frank, it looks absolutely disgusting.
That is quite a rude thing to say, Kapitan! The dish tastes quite nice - similar to good pickled herring, actually!
Just give it a try, Captain! I even gave you a good portion without any tails!
Let's not get distracted by the food. The main reason we're in the mess after hours is to figure out our next step with Yuri.
Da, Kapitan! Yuri was on a list to be purged. Marshal Voroshilov signed off on the execution order in 1937... yet here we are today, and Yuri is still with us.
Seems like Yuri was as slippery back then as he is now...
Like a jellied eel...

Fields.MenuText: This could be our chance to find something about Yuri's past to use against him.
I wonder how Yuri escaped getting purged...
Please don't compare Yuri to the jellied eels you two are eating...

Fields.DialogueText: I did not know you were such a picky eater, Kapitan!
Da, Kapitan. A man as bad as Yuri must have a long history of horrible deeds we can use against him.
I am not sure, but I wonder if the Party is aware that Yuri was so close to being executed...
If Yuri's name really was on an execution order signed by Marshal Voroshilov, that might explain why he's so insistent on getting rid of you, Voroshilov...
Da, I never understood why Yuri already seemed against me from the start.
I can have my associates do a little research on Yuri's past. If his name was on an official execution list, I'm sure we can find out more if we dig through all the old records.
If we find that he deceived the Party in the past to save himself, we can use this against him when the Party tries to arrest you, Kapitan.
It sounds like a long shot, but I suppose it's the only one we can take. Petty Officer Jones - please see what your friends can find on this Yuri of ours.
Aye-aye, Captain!
*BOOM*
Rusalki, Kapitan!
I've got to get back to the bridge! Voroshilov - please have the rest of my eels!
@BATTLE
We've got new orders from Moscow, Captain...
Let me take a look...
Kapitan, what do the orders say?
We're to change course immediately and sail to Novorossiysk.
We cannot do that, Kapitan. The Party will surely arrest you!
I know, Voroshilov - it's playing out just like Yuri said it would.
But we can't follow these orders, Captain!

Fields.MenuText: Don't worry, we're not sailing to Novorossiysk.
A good officer always obeys orders, huh?
Yuri was right - there's no escape for me!

Fields.DialogueText: Good thing you're a terrible officer, Captain. You did lock up a Party representative, after all.
That's the spirit, Captain!
You can't give up on us yet, Captain!
We need more time so Petty Officer Jones' associates can investigate Yuri's past. If Yuri made an underhanded deal to avoid execution, we can use that against him when we talk to the Party.
I'm sure we'll be able to dig up something on Yuri. The man doesn't exactly strike me as a saint, and he's had a long career in the Party already.
We can't ignore Moscow for too long, but we can do our best to chart courses that make it look like we're following orders.
In the meantime, your people need to find something useful on Yuri, Petty Officer Jones. It's the only hope we've got!
Rusalki ahead, Kapitan!
@BATTLE
The headaches have gone away for now, Kapitan.
That's good news. I'm assuming the dream about signing the execution list hasn't come back either?
No, Kapitan. It has been... nice.
In fact, I had a new dream about Marshal Voroshilov last night. It was quite pleasant.
Huh - so no more battles or executions this time?
No, Kapitan. Marshal Voroshilov was sitting eating dinner with his wife - Ekaterina. They talked about how their children were doing... and that was it.

Fields.MenuText: That sounds refreshingly normal.
I wonder why you're dreaming about that.
That hardly sounds like useful intelligence to me.

Fields.DialogueText: Da, Kapitan - at the end of the day, even a Marshal of the Soviet Union has to have dinner with his family.
Sometimes dreams are just dreams, Kapitan.
Is that my sole purpose in life, Kapitan? To collect intelligence?
Oh... well, of course not, Voroshilov!
Sometimes it feels that way...
Well, I suppose it's a good sign that you can have perfectly normal dreams.
The Party has been watching me ever since I appeared. They always talked of security threats and intelligence gathering... I wonder what a normal life is really like, Kapitan.
I hate to break it to you, Voroshilov, but what we're doing out here at sea will never be considered normal.
Da, Kapitan - I am starting to understand that.
*GUNFIRE*
Time to sink the Rusalki again, Kapitan!
@BATTLE
Welcome to Bulgaria, Voroshilov!
Another late-night change of course to a neutral port, Kapitan?
We've got to stay one step ahead of the Party while Petty Officer Jones' contacts try to find some useful info on Yuri.
Perfectly timed, Captain. I have news.
You seem excited, so I suppose it's good?
I hope so. It's nothing definite yet, but they've found a few informants with ties to Yuri - and it seems like he made a lot of enemies in his early days with the Party.

Fields.MenuText: I'm sure if they keep digging, they'll find something we can use against him.
If he was on an execution list and managed to escape, he must have made friends as well as enemies...

Fields.DialogueText: Well, I don't think you make friends in the Party by just being nice, Captain. He must have bribed or threatened his way out of execution somehow.

Fields.MenuText: Yuri isn't exactly a likeable guy. I'm sure everyone hated his guts.

Fields.DialogueText: You don't have to be likeable to be powerful, Captain.
I think so too, Captain. He's too much of a weasel to have a clean past.
It goes without saying, but we don't have much time. If your associates suspect they can find anything useful against Yuri, we need it as soon as possible.
Da, Petty Officer Jones. Please tell your friends to act quickly. We can only cruise around the Black Sea for so long before Moskva realizes we do not intend to return.
Believe me, Lady Voroshilov, I'm telling them to work as quickly as they can! Yuri already knows that I'm a spy, so I'd like to avoid a holiday in a Soviet gulag too.
Right. Well, finish up what you have to with the time we have left in port. We can't stay here much longer.
There are Rusalki approaching the harbor, Kapitan! We will have to fight our way back out to sea!
@BATTLE
We are being followed, Kapitan.
What do you mean?
Ever since we left Bulgaria, there has been a ship following us.
Really? There aren't any other ships close to us...
It is barely on the horizon, directly behind us - they definitely know what they are doing, Kapitan.

Fields.MenuText: It makes sense that the Red Fleet would send a ship after us.
How can we get rid of them?
Are you sure you're not seeing things? Maybe it's just a merchant ship.

Fields.DialogueText: The ship has tracked us precisely, and we are not following a shipping lane, Kapitan. It is following us intentionally.
Da, Kapitan. We cannot ignore their orders and expect to be forgotten.
Assuming that sinking them is not a viable option, there is not much we can do.
Well, you always brag about how our engines put out more power than expected. Let's speed up and see if we can lose them.
We can try, Kapitan, but we are hardly the fastest ship on the Black Sea.
We don't really have any other options at the moment...
Da, and it does not help that we have a fleet of Rusalki straight ahead of us!
@BATTLE
Yes, Kapitan, of course the ship following us is from the Red Fleet! Did you really think you can disregard their orders to return to port?
We're not going back, Yuri.
Your fate is already sealed, Kapitan! You are starting to sound like Comrade Voroshilov - you cannot avoid the inevitable!
The only thing inevitable is that liars like you will be caught and punished, Yuri!
Ha! I miss the old days where you at least pretended to cooperate, Voroshilov!

Fields.MenuText: So you sent for this ship that's following us?
If they fire on us or try to force a boarding, we'll have to shoot back.
What makes you think this ship can force us back to land?

Fields.DialogueText: Oh-ho! So you intend on getting into even more trouble with the Party?
I did not send for it personally, Kapitan, but it is a predictable end to your little Black Sea cruise.
A crew must listen to its captain - and Voroshilov will be the same, once you are boarded and replaced with an officer that demonstrates a little more loyalty.
This is ridiculous, Yuri! We haven't disobeyed any Red Fleet orders, so you can call off this ship of yours.
You have falsely imprisoned an official representative of the Party, Kapitan! It goes without saying that the Red Fleet would never approve of such an action.

Even if this ship catches us, there will be a mutiny if they try to replace the Kapitan. We have already been through so much - the crew has more loyalty to the Kapitan than to some smoke-filled room.
I suppose we will find out soon enough, Comrade Voroshilov!
@BATTLE
Yuri's ship appears to be gaining on us, Kapitan!
Full speed ahead! These waters are full of Morganas - and now we have to worry about getting boarded by another Soviet ship?
There is nothing we can do to stop them from boarding if they catch up to us, Kaptain. Yuri is right - trying to fight them off would only get you into even more trouble with the Red Fleet.
I'm glad you think the crew would support me if the boarding party tried to replace me with another captain, but that would cause an even bigger mess that I don't want to think about.
But it is true, Kapitan! You have commanded the ship through countless victories against the Rusalki. The crew would not easily accept a replacement - especially if it was forced on them.

Fields.MenuText: Good to know the crew has my back. I've always done my best to support them too.
Maybe one or two of them will even shed a tear when the Party leads me away in chains...
I've always fought for the crew and our mission - the only problem I've had is with Yuri!

Fields.DialogueText: Da, Kapitan. Yuri did try to blow up the ship, after all... I don't think any sane person outside the Party would support him for that.
The crew can tell that you care about them, Kapitan. That is why we all work so well together, even through this horrible war with the Rusalki.
Do not talk like that, Kapitan! You are not going anywhere!
Well, it seems like we're managing to pull away a bit from that ship that's following us...
Da, but it will be difficult to maintain this speed - especially if we encounter any more Rusalki. It is a real possibility that the ship catches us eventually...
You're right... we can't run forever. Petty Officer Jones needs to get back to us soon with any information we can use against Yuri.
Da, and in the meantime we need to avoid running into too many Rusalki that will slow us down.
That'll be a tough thing to avoid in these waters, Voroshilov. We've already got Morganas ahead of us!
@BATTLE
That's a huge fleet of Rusalki ahead of us, Kapitan!
We've got to slow down to engage them. That Soviet ship is bound to catch up with us now - if these Morganas don't sink us first!
It is a difficult situation, but no one will sink us, Kapitan! I have the guns ready!
Commence firing!
*GUNFIRE*
That's a hell of a lot of Morganas out there, Captain! Looks like Voroshilov is already landing on target, though!
She'd better land on target - it's the only way we'll be able to fight our way out of here before we're completely surrounded!

I got word from my associates looking into Yuri's past! They found some damning evidence that Yuri paid a lot of bribes to avoid execution. They're sending the full report on a supply ship to meet us.

Fields.MenuText: That's exactly the leverage we need to get Yuri to change his attitude!
It'll be tough for the Party to believe Yuri's side of the story if we tell them about his past.
Finally! We've got some evidence to wipe the smile off that rat's face!

Fields.DialogueText: Aye, Captain! I can't wait to see the look on Yuri's face when we tell him what we know!
Aye, Captain! Seems like he paid out half a dozen bribes to officials at all levels in the Party - they won't like hearing all of this!
He's going to get what he deserves, Captain!
Kapitan! These Rusalki are much stronger than the ones we have faced in the past!
Just keep firing, Voroshilov! We don't have a lot of other options right now!
Da, Kapitan! We are running low on ammunition as well, but we will make every shot count!
*BOOM*
@BATTLE
We just received the report on Yuri, Captain!
I'm amazed that British supply ship was able to get through all those Morganas and come alongside us!
Aye, Captain! It took some clever sailing to avoid all the Morganas, but nothing the Royal Navy can't handle! We'll start reading through the report and give you a summary as soon as we can.
Thanks, Petty Officer Jones - hopefully the intel is as good as promised.
I hope so too, Captain!
Oh, yes. This report has many interesting details, Kapitan.
Anything good so far?
It is a long list - several bribes to Party officials in 1937... but also ties to the White Army and the Tsar, and even trading secrets with the Germans in 1915 if we look back far enough!
Sounds like Yuri - playing every side just to help himself.
I had the feeling that Yuri was not a true believer in the Revolution, Kapitan! The Party should remove him at once!

Fields.MenuText: I just want Yuri off my ship. What the Party decides to do with him isn't my concern.
The Revolution will only succeed with good leadership. Yuri must be removed!
Yuri is just another opportunist!

Fields.DialogueText: I am sure they will not treat him kindly after reading everything in this report, Kapitan.
Da, Kapitan! This is the only way the proletariat can hold on to their power!
It is wreckers like him that hold back good working people, Kapitan!
We can talk more about politics later, but here comes another line of Morganas!
We will crush anyone who stands in the way of the Revolution, Kapitan!
@BATTLE
It's a pretty long report, Yuri. What I've read to you so far is only the first page.
When the Party reads about everything you have done, you should consider yourself lucky if they only send you to the Gulag for the rest of your life.
How... how do know all of this?!
There is fear in your eyes, Yuri Ivanovich! How the tables have turned...
You - you cannot give this information to the Party!

Fields.MenuText: Sounds like you're finally ready to cooperate, Yuri.
I suppose you could always bribe your way out of another execution...
Wait until the Party hears about all the great things you did for the Tsar before you decided to change sides!

Fields.DialogueText: I'll do anything! You can't let the Party have any of that information!
Please, Kapitan! I beg you - please do not give that report to the Party!
That... that was so long ago... but now you know everything! The Party must not see this report, Kapitan!
Is this why you wanted to monitor me so closely, Yuri? Is it because Marshal Voroshilov personally signed the order for your execution?
You are a worthless excuse of a man. The Soviet Union does not need rats like you in charge.
*BOOM*
That Morgana fleet is still out there, Voroshilov! We need to get back to battle stations!
We will talk more later, Yuri. You can use this time to think of all the excuses to give to the Party when they come to drag you away!
@BATTLE
Nice shooting, Voroshilov!
Spasiba, Kapitan! The Rusalki are quite strong! They are taking many hits, but we will keep shooting until we sink them!
Keep it up! I can already see another line approaching after this one. Seems like there's no end to them!
So what did Yuri say when you showed him the report, Captain?

Fields.MenuText: He changed his tune immediately! I've never seen a man shake in fear like that!
The Morganas attacked before we could decide on anything, but he's defintely willing to cooperate now.
That smug little rat finally shut his mouth for once.

Fields.DialogueText: We've got him exactly where we want him, Captain!
He hasn't got much room to negotiate now, Captain!
I can't wait to see that horrible man finally get what he deserves!
I haven't quite decided whether to negotiate with Yuri or just turn over the whole report to the Party.
It's a complicated situation. There's always the chance the Party ignores the report - and there's no guarantee they'll immediately arrest Yuri, even if they do read the whole thing.
That's true. I suppose the safest thing would be to negotiate with him now that we've got the leverage - but even that isn't guaranteed...
We should have just thrown Yuri overboard a long time ago, Kapitan...
I appreciate the political advice, Voroshilov, but we need to focus on taking care of these Morganas for now!
@BATTLE
The Rusalki have kept us for too long, Kapitan! That Soviet ship following us has finally caught up!
Sinking so many Morganas made it easier for them to get closer too...
Would you rather have us stop sinking the Rusalki? If we stop fighting them, we will not stay afloat for very long!
Of course not, Voroshilov! Keep up the fight! We've got Petty Officer Jones' report on Yuri in hand, so I'm not afraid to talk to Party officials if they want to come on board.
That is good to know, Kapitan, because the Soviet ship looks like it is coming alongside now. I can see a boarding party on their deck.

Fields.MenuText: Let's invite them on board. We're both Soviet ships.
Don't worry - we've got nothing to be afraid of.
They'll never take me alive, Voroshilov!

Fields.DialogueText: Please calm down, Kapitan! Remember that we have the report on Yuri, so I do not expect the Party to arrest you.
Da, Kapitan. Once they come on board, we can explain everything about Yuri.
Da, our report on Yuri has a long list of his past crimes. His word will mean nothing once the Party hears about all he has done.
This isn't over yet, so we'll need to stay sharp while we talk things over with our visitors.
Da, but these Rusalki are not making things any easier! There is another line of them coming over the horizon!
We'll have to take care of these Morganas before we can even think about giving our comrades a proper welcome!
@BATTLE
There are still more Rusalki ahead, Kapitan!
Let's take care of these Morganas, then we can figure out what to do with Yuri!
@BATTLE
The Party representatives are on board now, Yuri. They're waiting to talk to me.
... and what do you intend to say to them, Kapitan?
This report here is a list of every bad deed you've done over the last 25 years... or at least every bad deed we could find out about.
I am sure we did not find every bad deed, Yuri Ivanovich, but the report is still 72 pages long. It is full of treason, espionage, lies, assassinations, bribes, and corruption...
In addition, there are acts of support for royalists, capitalists, and foreign nations that are enemies of the Soviet Union. None of this would look good on the resume of a high-ranking Party member.
... so what do you want from me, Comrade Voroshilov?
I want you off this ship and out of our lives forever. The Kapitan will stay in place and continue all duties as our captain. You will also explain the bombing as an accidental fire.
Most importantly, you will remind the Party that you have found no evidence showing that I have any ability at all to read the mind of Marshal Voroshilov. Tell them to leave me alone.
... and in return I have your word that this report remains a secret to the world?

Fields.MenuText: I hate bargaining with a lowlife like you, but yes - that's our deal.
If you ever go back on your word, we have plenty of copies to send to the Party.
That's right - you've avoided another execution, Yuri.

Fields.DialogueText: It seems like we both have things to gain from this arrangement, Kapitan. You are very kind to agree to a deal.
That seems like adequate motivation for me to uphold my end of the bargain, Kapitan... and of course you are a very honorable officer who would never go back on a deal.
I don't need your flattery, Yuri - but yes, I can assure you we will keep our end of the bargain as long as you do the same.
I do have a way of always coming out on top, Kapitan. Nonetheless, I do appreciate your generous cooperation with our agreement.
Well. I suppose it's time to let me out of the brig, then?
Only because it is finally time for you to leave this ship, Yuri Ivanovich!
The Party representatives believed everything Yuri told them, and Yuri is heading back to the mainland on their ship. What a relief, huh?
Da, Kapitan - but we need to fight off these Rusalki if any of us want to go anywhere!
@BATTLE
I hate the fact that we had to bargain with Yuri, Kapitan. It seems like he still got away with something...
Well, at least he's out of our lives now, and we can focus on fighting the war. Defeating the Morganas is far more important than wasting energy on Yuri.
Do you think the Party will monitor me less closely after Yuri explains that I cannot read Marshal Voroshilov's mind?

Fields.MenuText: They should leave you alone. Yuri was only paranoid because Marshal Voroshilov signed his execution.
Of course! Why would the Party monitor you when it's obvious you can't read Marshal Voroshilov's mind?
It's hard to say - not everything the Party does makes sense.

Fields.DialogueText: I hope they will finally give me some privacy, Kapitan. It is hard to concentrate on our mission when I am constantly being watched.
I hope the Party will make the right decision this time, Kapitan. I do not pose a security threat at all, and their constant interference distracts me from our mission.
I do not like to admit it, but you are right, Kapitan.
Well, now that Yuri's gone, at least we have one less thing to worry about.
*FOOTSTEPS*
Greetings, Kapitan. My name is Mikhail Petrov. Thank you for having me on board.
Wait, are you from that Soviet ship we just met up with? They just left, so you missed getting back on board!
Da, Kapitan - I am from that ship, but I was not supposed to get back on board.
... what do you mean?
The Party appointed me to replace Yuri Ivanovich. I am the new Party representative assigned to watch over Comrade Voroshilov. I look forward to sailing with you!
Zdravstvuyte, Mikhail Petrov. I am Voroshilov.
Of course you are, Comrade Voroshilov! I have read so much about you from Yuri Ivanovich's reports. You are quite... fascinating!
I suppose the Party will always find me interesting, Mikhail Petrov - it was just a foolish dream to think otherwise...
